posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
This is a Battle Cleric with Devastating Critical.

I have seached the old and new archives after a similar build. In the old archives there are few strength builds with this class combination and none that have Dev crit. With our new ECB filter (beta) there came up four builds with cleric and Dev crit: We have the Blade Juggernaut and Chaos Harbinger from the Legacy builds. Then we have Orion's Unholy Hurricane of Death. The build that structurally is closest to mine is Mithdradates' Hierophant of Velsharoon  even if it is a bard/PM build and as such has other qualities.

The Devastator priest is built as a combat cleric with focus on reaching an undispellable level without too much delay. Monk adds class skills, better saves, Evasion and Cleave as a bonus feat. CoT gives the Martial proficiency, improves the saves and adds much needed feats. A high Fortitude save protects in a Dev crit environment. I have focused on maintaining BAB+15 at level 20 for full effect of Divine pover. AB will not be a problem with clerics anyway since they can buff to the cap. As for domains, I chose Trickery and Travel. Trickery is there for access to the Improved invisibility spell with 50% concealment. Feel free to choose something else than Travel if there are perma-haste items available. The skill points in Heal are not essential for the build idea, so put them where you want.

Pros: Power, POWER, POWER, POWER
Cons: If you think Cleric with Dev Crit is too overpowered.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Now that's what I'm talking about! I reckon even I could play this one, Mick. And how many builds do you know where the Dev Crit DC is higher than the AB? I know that's only on paper, but still, kewl!

I like it so much that I've only got 1 question. Much as I love Morning Star - and I do, underrepresented as it is in terms of quality ones available in many environments - I assume you're taking it purely to open up CoT for you. Thus, is it maybe better focusing in it later: say at level 9 rather than 3? Is that +1AB better than earlier Blind Fight and Empower? You'll know better than I, but I merely ask for clarification.

I did have a second question, but realized it was stupid because I answered it myself while I was typing it. At least it shows I'm both learning and paying attention!

A more than welcome addition to the canon. (See what I did there? Canon...cleric...Oh, suit yourselves.) 👏

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Yeah, someone had to do the right thing.
We begged BC for a moon or two - I heard he would be ready by Christmas, then we laid-down some sample builds about powerful Clerics with CoT ourselves, but none of us made the leap & put those things in their correct place, except Mick. And Mick dagger, being the revolutionary that he is, did it with Monk as a tertiary class, not because its necessarily better, but because he can. And it works flawlessly!
I have a build of mine of course, (Joan of Arc), that does have Dev Crit & all, but it's buried in the unfinished section of the ECB, so she doesn't count.
Oh, & about the "Power" thing...Nobody does it better than JC, not even the Emperor Palpatine, himself. See for yourself,

Though, to be fair, I think Hip finally snapped after filling in schedules for many, many other builds in short order when pulling the Filter together. Black Cobra is, of course, still more than welcome to post his build - I tried nudging him once already. He'd initially said he'd do it in a month (nearly two months ago). It was kalistez who mockingly suggested it'd be ready by Christmas - and then didn't even specify Christmas of which year.

Thank you! 🙂
Let me hear how you fare if you try the build.
I guess you can swap the early feats if you like. I put it the way I did because I wanted that +1 AB sooner rather than later. As for BF, it is my impression that I seldom come across concealed creatures before level 6.
SpoilerEmpower comes at Cleric level 8, just before you get level 5 spells. The thinking is that you don't want to put empowered level 2 spells on level 4 slots before you can extend Divine power.

posts.author: Aquarius 233
posts.content:
Like the build!
The things I appreciate the most are:
  • empowered spells at 9th level; and
  • the metamagic trick described on post #5.
When building clerics, I have always given precedence of AB boosting and defensive feats over metamagic ones. However, extend spells can be handy also in mid-ten levels. And empower spells too, never thought of that (I have taken this feat always at level 18)....

posts.author: fallander69
posts.content:
Okay, i played this guy a little while then re-made it  anew.
I was missing some better AC. Taking Plant for the reason is good idea, as the lvl 5 and 6 spells are overcrowded with goodies anyway, so it left you with very little room for haste, imo way more practical was to have barkskin at lvl 2.
Summons play very important role when solo so yeah Animal domain all the way and cats grace +2AC (or more if empowered) 
Instead of Extended spell at first lvl (why??) i chose expertise. In total, with spells, expertise and standard gear can get to 33AC from the very early levels, which is quite good i think.  This is of course entirely for WoG, from my very limited experience. Lawful neutral, Obad-Hai.  
Happy Christmas (or whatever left from it :P).

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
Do summons hold throughout or so you need to transition at some point? I have the feeling summons are beginning to fade in value for me in early epics and I am not keen on building for that. Meaning why animal over war if your summons are not useful after 25th level for example?

I have stalled my character for a bit as I try to sort out if I took the right domains.


Sent from my iPhone using Tapatalk

posts.author: Orion
posts.content: The summons do fall off in mid epic levels, I can't answer your question whether War or Animal is better, if it helps Zanithar, I played a Druid to 40, and my level 9 spell book was mostly SoV with maybe 2-3 Summon Creature IX's

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Pre-levels 30, Animal Domain is pretty good - after level 30 (call it an arbitrary goalpost), Summons, even the Epic, buffed versions are overwhelmingly useless other than to momentarily distract m0bs, opponents, etc.

Then War Domain would be better.

However, when weighing which is best, I consider 30 levels of very good usefulness vs ~15 to be the deciding point.

Esp. early levels Animal Domain is really good!

And what is not to like about Elemental Princes?

Sent from my SM-G955F using Tapatalk

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
A tactic that works well is to have your Summons "Hold their ground" at a pre-determined place, go out, lure an opponent, engage it, and then set your Summons to "Attack nearest".

This will normally put your summons to good use, without losing it to damage (as the opponent in question is trying to smash your head off, instead).

Rinse, repeat.

Sent from my SM-G955F using Tapatalk

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Thats a good point in distracting mobs Web in epic levels which I forgot
Summons are good for escapes, and the stronger they are the more time you get, particularly elementals who are crit immune, sneak immune, mind immune, and I think the princes/princesses are also knockdown immune
My main strategy for this is was to cast a summon, use an invis pot and potion of speed then run

In terms of buffing summons, pretty much as a druid the only buffs I might cast would be stoneskin and/or barkskin on summons, the earth elemental will cast it stoneskin anyway, and barkskin's pretty moot later on, even +5 AC can't really help improve their abysmal AC
Other classes (trickery domain clerics, sorcerer, wizards and bards) would have improved invisibility which in theory make summons last 25-50% longer against physical damage mobs depending on whether these enemies have blind fight or not, which I think is pretty attractive if you can spare a single cast on it

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
You can buff their AC to the +20 limit with 1 level of PDK on WoG.

It makes them a little more durable.

Sent from my SM-G955F using Tapatalk

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
fallander69 wrote:
Dec 26, 2019
Okay, i played this guy a little while then re-made it  anew.
I was missing some better AC. Taking Plant for the reason is good idea, as the lvl 5 and 6 spells are overcrowded with goodies anyway, so it left you with very little room for haste, imo way more practical was to have barkskin at lvl 2.
Summons play very important role when solo so yeah Animal domain all the way and cats grace +2AC (or more if empowered) 
Instead of Extended spell at first lvl (why??) i chose expertise. In total, with spells, expertise and standard gear can get to 33AC from the very early levels, which is quite good i think.  This is of course entirely for WoG, from my very limited experience. Lawful neutral, Obad-Hai.  
Happy Christmas (or whatever left from it :P). 
This is good feedback from early leveling on WoG. AC is important there and starting out with dex 8 may pose a challenge early on before you get dex gear and the AC buffs start to kick in. 
Expertise is a good feat for temporary AC. The question is if you really need it as a cleric later in the game.
You ask why Extend spell at lvl 1? Extend is there for the 1 round per level spells and for Divine Favor to last 2 turns rather than only 1. It comes at lvl 1 because none of the other feats are available or better to take that early.
The build was not tailored to any specific module or PW. Like most generic builds you can tweak it to fit the environment where you play.
I look forward to hearing how it performs on WoG at higher levels.

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
Mick, since you are about and weighing in, what are your thoughts on 24 Cleric / 10 COT / 6 Monk? If I went this direction, what feat do I drop, Epic Prowess?

Never mind, no feat loss to take Monk 6 ... drop level 1 knockdown and pull great cleave back into pre epics. Net +10% move and improved knockdown. All good.

Sent from my iPad using Tapatalk

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Zanithar wrote:
Dec 27, 2019
Mick, since you are about and weighing in, what are your thoughts on 24 Cleric / 10 COT / 6 Monk?  If I went this direction, what feat do I drop, Epic Prowess?

Never mind, no feat loss to take Monk 6 ...
Monk 6 wil give more tumble drops and finally a very late IKD. You will lose one Great Wisdom from the bonus feat at cleric 26. I see no compelling reason to make this change.

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
Fair enough, I was considering making the change as a derivative. Upon closer examination I can keep the Great Wisdom and net Improved Knockdown at no feat cost. This is accomplished by dropping level 1 knockdown, pulling Great Cleave into the sub 20 feat schedule and pushing the second CoT level to level 21 to preserve the suggested Great Wisdom loss.

The net result is the non-trivial QoL cost of trading the existing level 1 knockdown for level 37 improved knockdown, Immune Disease, 1 AC at level 5 and of course the +10% speed bonus. A cost I am willing to accept but probably is not the best generic build choice, unless the goal is strongest level 40 build mechanically or you are on a server with Knockdown items.

Regardless, thanks for the feedback and thanks for the build, I find it very interesting and will give it a, slightly modified, twirl and let you know how it fares.


Sent from my iPad using Tapatalk

posts.author: Revik
posts.content: Why does this build need WF: MorningStar at all?  I'm new to WOG, so maybe there's a special rule change there.  According to the NWN wiki, COT simply requires "Feats: weapon focus in a melee weapon".  The WF: Scimitar would suffice according to that definition.

posts.author: Revik
posts.content: Ah, I figured it out.  You don't have Martial Weapons yet, so you need a WF in any simple weapon.  Got it.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Revik wrote:
Mar 16, 2020
Why does this build need WF: MorningStar at all?  I'm new to WOG, so maybe there's a special rule change there. 
The build is not made with any specific module or PW in mind, but the mod must of course support Dev crit.
The WF Morningstar is just as you found out to qualify for CoT. I could of course have take WP Martial and then WF Scimitar. But the way I do it I get a "free" second WF.

posts.author: demoix
posts.content: This bad boy is like a knife through the butter, wiping enemies on my OC run right now like no tomorrow! One of the favorite builds for me at the moment. It has good melee capabilities, good spells in various situations and have huge defence with full plate and shield, while Tomi is dealing with traps and locks and also stabs enemies from the back while I'm holding the front.

posts.author: mikazu
posts.content: Joining the party a couple of years later. I am trying this build on OC and then will also use it on HOU. Right now, as demoix said, it is doing really well. I do have a couple of questions. Which gear do you suggest (other than the scimitar)? Should I use full armor and a shield? Don't they negate the Monk Wisdom AC bonus?  Which stats should I prioritize with the gear? Also, the low Charisma and no persuasion hurt the campaign gameplay; what could I exchange in terms of skills to help with that?

posts.author: demoix
posts.content:
mikazu wrote:
Dec 29, 2024
Joining the party a couple of years later. I am trying this build on OC and then will also use it on HOU. Right now, as demoix said, it is doing really well. I do have a couple of questions. Which gear do you suggest (other than the scimitar)? Should I use full armor and a shield? Don't they negate the Monk Wisdom AC bonus?  Which stats should I prioritize with the gear? Also, the low Charisma and no persuasion hurt the campaign gameplay; what could I exchange in terms of skills to help with that?
@mikazu  Yes, use a full plate and shield. Monk levels are for Cleave, Evasion, and skill dumps for tumble. A morningstar weapon is quite decent for a cleric early on. After COT levels, choose any weapon you like, it doesn't matter. I have chosen the longsword because I like it, and there are typically a lot of good longswords available in most modules, not just in OC or HOTU. Regarding charisma, it is low, so we come to the conclusion that you can't have everything naturally. But at least a 14 INT score gives you more skills, so you can pump diplomacy or other social skill on every level, which will help you.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: If I should prioritize the persuade skill, I would pick points from heal. In the OC, you can also get some gear with bonuses to Cha and Persuade that you may equip when needed.

posts.author: mikazu
posts.content:
Thanks @Mick Dagger and @demoix 

One last question, @demoix , you mentioned using longsword later on, I assume you switch the build weapon focus from Scimitar to Longsword right?

posts.author: demoix
posts.content:
mikazu wrote:
Dec 30, 2024
Thanks @Mick Dagger and @demoix 

One last question, @demoix , you mentioned using longsword later on, I assume you switch the build weapon focus from Scimitar to Longsword right?
@mikazu Yes, the first weapon focus is for Morningstar in the early game to help you better start up and the second weapon focus is when you achieve COT levels by choosing anything else instead of Scimitar. The reason the Scimitar was chosen by OP is because it has the best crit range, and this build is focused on devastating crits in the late game, which is key to getting critical hits.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
mikazu wrote:
Dec 29, 2024
Joining the party a couple of years later. I am trying this build on OC and then will also use it on HOU. Right now, as demoix said, it is doing really well. I do have a couple of questions. Which gear do you suggest (other than the scimitar)? Should I use full armor and a shield? Don't they negate the Monk Wisdom AC bonus?  Which stats should I prioritize with the gear? Also, the low Charisma and no persuasion hurt the campaign gameplay; what could I exchange in terms of skills to help with that?
You say you're going OC and HotU, so it might be worth thinking about going into the Sands of Fate modules afterwards (available from the Vault: there's a thread for it in our Modules forum), otherwise you won't be able to make use of the focus of this build, which is Devastating Critical. You'll probably finish HotU at around level 28, so you'll need a few more levels for the feat, and SoF goes all the way to level 40.

That said, this build works very well even before taking Dev Crit.

EDIT: Oh, and taking morning star early is also helpful against undead (blunt weapons work best against them, by and large), and you'll meet a lot of them at early levels in the OC.
